column2: An unordered collection of distinct elements. Notation: {1, 2, 3}. Key operations: union (∪), intersection (∩), difference (−), complement (Aᶜ).

column1: What is the difference between a set and a multiset?
column2: A set contains each element at most once. A multiset (bag) allows duplicate elements.

column1: What is the Cartesian product A × B?
column2: The set of all ordered pairs (a, b) where a ∈ A and b ∈ B. |A × B| = |A| × |B|.
A subset of the Cartesian product A × B. A binary relation on A is a subset of A × A. Generalizes concepts like "less than" or "is a friend of."
A relation that is reflexive (a R a), symmetric (a R b → b R a), and transitive (a R b ∧ b R c → a R c). Partitions a set into equivalence classes.
A relation that is reflexive, antisymmetric (a R b ∧ b R a → a = b), and transitive. Example: ≤ on integers, ⊆ on sets.

column1: What is a function (in discrete math)?
column2: A relation where each element of the domain maps to exactly one element of the codomain. f: A → B. Properties: injective (one-to-one), surjective (onto), bijective (both).

column1: What is the difference between injective, surjective, and bijective?
column2:
Injective (one-to-one): distinct inputs map to distinct outputs.
Surjective (onto): every output has at least one input.
Bijective: both — a perfect one-to-one correspondence.
If n+1 items are placed into n containers, at least one container holds 2 or more items. Generalized: if kn+1 items into n containers, some container holds ≥ k+1 items.
An ordered arrangement of r items from n distinct items. P(n, r) = n! / (n−r)!. Order matters.
An unordered selection of r items from n distinct items. C(n, r) = n! / (r! × (n−r)!). Order does not matter.

column1: What is Pascal's Triangle and its relation to combinations?
column2: Each entry is C(n, k). Each value is the sum of the two values above it. The nth row gives the coefficients of the binomial expansion (a + b)ⁿ.
(a + b)ⁿ = Σ C(n,k) aᵏ bⁿ⁻ᵏ for k=0 to n. The coefficients C(n,k) are binomial coefficients.

column1: What is a graph in discrete math?
column2: G = (V, E) where V is a set of vertices and E is a set of edges (pairs of vertices). Can be directed or undirected, weighted or unweighted.

column1: What is a tree in graph theory?
column2: A connected, acyclic undirected graph with |E| = |V| − 1. A rooted tree has one designated root node.
Assigning colors to vertices so no two adjacent vertices share the same color. The chromatic number χ(G) is the minimum colors needed. Application: scheduling, register allocation.

column1: What is a Hamiltonian path vs an Eulerian path?
column2:
Eulerian path: visits every edge exactly once. Eulerian circuit exists iff all vertices have even degree.
Hamiltonian path: visits every vertex exactly once. NP-complete to determine in general.
Arithmetic with a modulus n where numbers "wrap around." a ≡ b (mod n) means n divides (a − b). Used in cryptography, hashing, and number theory.
An efficient method to compute GCD(a, b): GCD(a, b) = GCD(b, a mod b), with base case GCD(a, 0) = a. Runs in O(log min(a,b)) time.

A proof technique with two steps:
1. Base case: prove the statement holds for n = 0 (or 1).
2. Inductive step: assume it holds for n = k (inductive hypothesis) and prove it holds for n = k+1.
